title: Functional Depression Is Still Depression

content: A common misconception is that you’re only depressed if you can’t get out of bed or you’re crying all day long. It can be easy for depression to creep in without you noticing when you have this mentality.
I didn’t realize I was depressed because I was able to go to work.
I didn’t realize I was depressed because I was able to maintain relationships with my friends and family.
I didn’t realize I was depressed because getting out of bed every day wasn’t an impossible task.
I didn’t realize I was depressed because I wasn’t having to convince myself to stay alive.
It seeped into the cracks of my life without me realizing.

This showed up in me being easily irritated. It showed up in feeling fatigued more often. It showed up in procrastination of tasks that need to get done. It showed up in making excuses for not doing as many activities. It showed up in the urge to isolate and stay home more and more often.

content: When I’m functionally depressed but don’t realize it, I’m not prepared for how much something minor affects me emotionally. A minor incident could occur, and suddenly, my mood tanks. It’s difficult to turn things around after that.
This confused me at first. Why is my body reacting as if I’m depressed when I’m not? This is why being functionally depressed is still depressed.

Identifying when I’m functionally depressed helps keep me from getting to the point where depression is severely affecting my day-to-day life. It’s unlikely I’ll just wake up one day in the depths again. It may feel like it hit suddenly, but if I look back at my habits and how I’ve been feeling lately, there is normally a sign I was depressed before this point.

Having emotional check-ins with yourself is the best way to notice if you’re functionally depressed. I think a lot of people get in autopilot mode and don’t stop to think about how they’ve been feeling lately. I ask myself if I’ve been more reactionary lately, unmotivated to do things I love, isolative, and just overall not feeling like myself.

content: I do things weekly that are positive for my mental health, so when I feel myself not wanting to do them as much, I ask myself why. Normally, this is an indication that my depression may be starting to creep back in. The sooner you identify a depressive episode, the sooner you can start doing things to work through it. Climbing out of a dark hole is a lot easier when you’re only halfway down instead of at the bottom.

I recently went through some life challenges, and I started to notice those functionally depressed behaviors come back. The urge to isolate. The urge to self-medicate. The urge to do the bare minimum to appear as a functioning human. But this time I caught myself. I knew what to look for.

It can be difficult to detect if someone in your life is depressed, functionally or otherwise. I recently had a close family member go through something catastrophic. When that happens, everything else gets put on the back burner. You’re in survival mode. So I did something for her that I knew she wouldn’t get done but would make her feel so much better. I deep cleaned her room, bathroom, and closet.

content: I made the space clutter free and peaceful. I also left a motivational note on her nightstand to find before she went to bed. She was so grateful and said it was the nicest thing anyone has ever done for her. Cleaning, cooking, running errands, completing a task they’ve been procrastinating, or just spending time with that person is a good way to show support.

If you’re functionally depressed, my advice is to be disciplined with yourself now while you still have some motivation. Do small things every day to improve your mental health. Be patient. It will get better.
